abstract.text: Information that represents the customer’s purchase of a product in your app.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A
transaction

represents a successful In-App Purchase. The App Store generates a transaction each time a customer purchases an In-App Purchase product or renews a subscription. For each transaction that represents a current purchase, your app unlocks the purchased content or service and finishes the transaction.
Use the
type to perform these transaction-related tasks:
Get the customer’s transaction history, latest transactions, and current entitlements to unlock content and services.
Access transaction properties.
Finish a transaction after your app delivers the purchased content or service.
Access the raw JSON Web Signature (JWS) string and supporting values to verify the transaction information.
Listen for new transactions while the app is running.
Begin a refund request from within your app.

content.text: Access transaction history and current entitlements

inlineContent.text: Your app doesn’t create transaction objects. Instead, StoreKit automatically makes up-to-date transactions available to your app, including when someone launches the app for the first time.
Session 110404:
You access transactions in several ways:
Get transaction history anytime by accessing the static
sequence, or get just the most recent transaction for a product with the
property of
Receive notifications for new transactions while your app is running when customers complete a purchase outside of the app, including on another device, through the transaction listener,
Access the latest transaction for a subscription group through the subscription status API, using
After a successful In-App Purchase, StoreKit returns the transaction through
The most important use of transaction information is for determining which In-App Purchases the customer has paid access to, so your app can unlock the content or service. The
API provides the information you need to unlock all of the customer’s paid content in your app. Use
to get a list of transactions for all the products the customer is currently entitled to, including non-consumable In-App Purchases and currently active subscriptions.
The App Store cryptographically signs transaction information in JWS format. StoreKit automatically validates and returns the signed information, wrapped in a
. When the
wraps a
value, it provides the raw JWS string in the
property. If you get a transaction through
, the information passed validation. If you get it through
, the information didn’t pass StoreKit’s automatic validation. Your app can immediately access the transaction information in the
To perform your own validation on the device, use the verification result’s
string, and use the provided convenience properties
, and
. For added control and security, send the
to your server to verify. Consider using the App Store Server Library to implement your verification. The library provides the functions

in each language the library supports. For more information, see

is the same as the

If StoreKit returns a transaction as verified, the transaction is valid for the device. For information about performing your own verification for a device, see
For more information about JWS, see the

content.text: Access purchases made with the original API

inlineContent.text: All In-App Purchases that customers make are equally available to your app in this
API, and in receipts using the
, as follows:
New purchases that customers make with the original API are available immediately using the
API.
Purchases that customers make with the
method are available in the original API when your app refreshes the receipt. For more information, see

abstract.text: Manage your customers’ App Store transactions from your server.
Transaction information signed by the App Store, in JSON Web Signature (JWS) Compact Serialization format.
Use Apple’s open source library to create JSON Web Tokens (JWT) to authorize your calls, verify transactions, extract transaction identifiers from receipts, and more.

doc://com.apple.documentation/documentat.title: Simplifying your implementation by using the App Store Server Library

abstract.text: Specify your secure server’s URL in App Store Connect to receive version 2 notifications.
Transaction information signed by the App Store, in JSON Web Signature (JWS) Compact Serialization format.
A Boolean value that determines whether StoreKit includes finished consumable In-App Purchases in transaction information.
Support In-App Purchases and interactions with the App Store.
Information about a product that you configure in App Store Connect.
The purchase succeeded and results in a transaction.
The latest transaction for the subscription group.
The most recent transaction for the product.
Initiates a purchase for the product with the App Store and displays the confirmation sheet.
A request to the App Store to get the app receipt, which represents the customer’s transactions with your app.
Information that represents the customer’s purchase of a product in your app.
Metadata for transactions that use the Advanced Commerce API.
The types of subscription offers for auto-renewable subscriptions.
The error codes for refund requests.
The status codes for refund requests.
An asynchronous sequence of transactions.
Metadata for transactions that use the Advanced Commerce API.
A sequence that emits all the customer’s transactions for your app.
Gets all the transactions associated with this product ID.
The unique identifier of the app download transaction.
Presents the refund request sheet for the specified transaction in a window scene.
Presents the refund request sheet for the specified transaction in a view controller.
Presents the refund request sheet for the transaction in a view controller.
Presents the refund request sheet for the transaction in a window scene.
Gets the latest transactions that entitle the customer to a specified product.
A sequence of the latest transactions that entitle a customer to In-App Purchases and subscriptions.
Gets the transactions that entitle the user to items purchased under a product ID.
The device verification value you use to verify whether the transaction belongs to the device.
The UUID for computing the device verification value.
Indicates to the App Store that the app delivered the purchased content or enabled the service to finish the transaction.
The JSON representation of the transaction information.
Gets the customer’s most recent transaction for an In-App Purchase.
The string representation of the offer period applied to the subscription offer for this transaction.
The date that the App Store signed the JWS transaction.
A sequence that emits unfinished transactions for the customer.
The asynchronous sequence that emits a transaction when the system creates or updates transactions that occur outside the app or on other devices.
A type that describes the result of a StoreKit verification.
The header component of the JWS transaction.
The transaction signed by the App Store, in JWS Compact Serialization format.
The payload component of the JWS transaction.
The signature component of the JWS transaction.
The associated value failed StoreKit automatic verification checks.
The associated value passed StoreKit automatic verification checks.
Select the type of receipt validation, on the device or on your server, that works for your app.
Use the latest API to support In-App Purchases in new or existing apps, or the original API to support In-App Purchases in earlier operating systems.

doc://com.apple.storekit/documentation/S.title: Choosing a StoreKit API for In-App Purchases

abstract.text: Offer additional content and services in your app using the Original In-App Purchase API.
Provide subscription service for customers who redeem offer codes through the App Store or within your app.

doc://com.apple.storekit/documentation/S.title: Supporting subscription offer codes in your app

abstract.text: Re-engage previous subscribers with a free or discounted offer for an auto-renewable subscription, for a specific duration.

doc://com.apple.storekit/documentation/S.title: Supporting win-back offers in your app

abstract.text: Verify that your app receives and handles transactions that occur outside your app, such as subscription purchases, renewals, and offer and promo code redemptions.

doc://com.apple.storekit/documentation/S.title: Testing purchases made outside your app

abstract.text: Test your app’s implementation of refund requests, and your app’s and server’s handling of approved and declined refunds.
Verify that your app receives and handles win-back offer transactions, including those made outside your app.

doc://com.apple.storekit/documentation/S.title: Testing win-back offers in the sandbox environment

abstract.text: The properties of a transaction, including identifiers, purchase and revocation dates and details, status, and offer details.
Verify transactions with the App Store on a secure server.

doc://com.apple.storekit/documentation/S.title: Validating receipts with the App Store

abstract.text: A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A class of types whose instances hold the value of an entity with stable identity.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose values can be implicitly or explicitly copied.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
